description: From Middle English forgon (“to go by, pass up”), from Old English forgān (“to go away, forgo”); equivalent to for- +‎ go.

verbs.description: forgo (third-person singular simple present forgoes, present participle forgoing, simple past forwent, past participle forgone) (transitive)

entries.meaning: To let pass, to leave alone, to let go.
To do without, to abandon, to renounce.
examples: You might think that Americans buy roughly the same number of fitted sheets as flats. Or, considering the market for electric blankets, duvets, and other covers, that consumers buy even more bottom sheets, simply forgoing the tops.

entries.meaning: To refrain from, to abstain from, to pass up, to withgo.
examples: I wouldn't forgo something, unless I'm convinced that it's detrimental in some way or another.
